reviewText: My One and Only stars Renee Zellweger in a movie that's mostly a drama, but contains a few elements of comedy every once in a while.Renee portrays a hoity toity-type woman who loves spending money and living elegantly.  She has an obsession with men too.  She develops relationships, and many times, her past relationships come back to haunt her as the boyfriends from her past make a surprise return and normally only play minor roles in the storyline.The storyline is mainly about Reene and her two teenage sons travelling across the country in search of... well I suppose in search of finding a satisfying lifestyle for the three of them.  At first they start out in the northeast section of the United States such as Boston, New York and Pittsburgh, and eventually they travel west to places in Missouri and eventually make their destination to Los Angeles.Throughout the adventure, they meet people who are either strange, crooked, or depressed (without spoiling too much).I believe My One and Only is an underrated film.  Kevin Bacon doesn't make much of an appearance, except for a couple short spots and that's pretty much it.The comedy usually takes a backseat to the drama segments, because the film is mainly about telling a family story dealing with a mother and her two sons struggling to get by and learn to deal with people.  The two teenage sons have problems of their own but neither character is ever touched upon deeply or creatively.  Instead, the two boys feel like they're only there to fill in as side characters while Renee's storyline receives most of the attention.A quality film worth watching.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I enjoyed this movie very much and watched it twice; it reminds me a little of the film, This Boys Life.  There's the mother's adventurous search for a new husband and life and her always-optimistic expectations versus the (sometimes comedic but often ruthless) reality and truth of how women were often treated in the 40's and 50's era.  There's a variety of interesting characters and experiences in the story with drama, unexpected twists and turns, irony, and sardonic comedy. The fashions, cars, and other pop culture shown are all attractive and colorful and look true to the era depicted, as I remember the 50's anyway.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I thought this would never end. It's an attempted throwback film, I guess, but I wasn't interested in the period sets or dress, and the dialogue was forced to be witty. There is no chemistry between Zellweger and any of the men she tries to woo, including Kevin Bacon, the bandleader scallawag husband she leaves in a huff. Though it's told through the eyes of one of her two sons, neither one was interestingly drawn as a character. I'm surprised this is vintage 2009. It seems older and more dated. I cannot recommend this.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Caught this on cable approx. Thanksgiving, 2010.  I hate to admit it, but I enjoyed this one.  Renee Zellweger's delivers, in my opinion, an excellent portrayal of a proper Southern Mom with seemingly Romantic notions of everything ending with a happy ending, even when it all falls apart.  And it does fall apart, more than once!  From her cheating husband, to her mentally-warped fiance (and serial bigamist)!  Somehow, she shoots for the sunny-side of the street.  Her two sons, they have their share of issues, also.  Ultimately, mom takes her sons across the country for the trip to Hollywood, to give her oldest son a chance to make it in the movies.  It doesn't quite work out that way, but see the movie, and you'll see what I mean!Overall:  I enjoyed it - and will purchase it at some point!I rate "My One and Only" 4 stars!
Title: N/A

reviewText: If nothing else,My One and Onlyalways keeps you on your toes. The movie follows Anne Deveraux (Renée Zellweger) and her two sons as she flees from a broken marriage and looks for a new life. Anne travels from New York to California looking for a new sugar daddy, but more often getting into trouble. One thing I really like about the movie is that the three main characters keep moving around, injecting new characters and plot twists constantly. Each potential suitor for Anne has a fatal flaw, from the overbearing military colonel to the insane matrimonialist. This isn't a cheery comedy, but I think you'll probably laugh at the absurdity of it all.
summary: "Your story is a bit exaggerated, isn't it?"

reviewText: I had not seen Renee in this type of film before & she was pretty good in this I thought. I always thought that she was a good actress anyway. The film quality was pretty nice as I thought at times this was Blu-ray quality. I do have a Blu-Ray upgrade deck and it makes regular dvd's sometimes look better than the regular dvd quality. I can't comment on the audio as I listen through external speakers hooked up to my stereo system, but it sounds good to me. I'm also glad they made this in the 2:35:1 aspect ratio as I prefer seeing the whole film. I don't mind the black bars at the top & bottom of the screen as some people do. My TV frame is black, & once I get into the movie, I don't notice the bars anyway. This also has [2] nice special features. I rated this a 4 only because it isn't a film I absolutely love, but one I really like.

Based on a true story told by George Hamilton from memories of his childhood.  The whole cast was excellent and I recommend it to anyone that enjoys a good life story movie.

reviewText: I had "My One and Only" on a list of recent movies I had missed and after viewing it, I was pleasantly surprised at how much I enjoyed this charming, slightly over-the-top film. Renée Zellweger plays the often beaten down but nonetheless driven mother of two teenage boys, whose own separation from her husband has her, quite literally, driven to leave him. And drive she and the boys do! From Boston to California, it's one missed opportunity after another as Zellweger runs into a cast of losing suitors...several played by actors of note.The pace is decidedly slow, but that makes "My One and Only" all the better. While Zellweger is the glue that holds the family (and the movie) together, a wonderful performance is turned in by Logan Lerman, who plays the older son George. George serves as narrator and his emotional expressiveness is just right for the part. I highly recommend "My One and Only" and I wouldn't be surprised if the viewer might want to see it for a second time.

reviewText: I enjoyed this movie much more than I expected to. Not being a George Hamilton fan, don't dislike him, just never "discovered" him, I didn't expect much but I love Renee Zellweger and so decided to watch this. Kevin Bacon does an excellent job bringing to life a band leader who is very good at leading a bad but sucks at being a husband and father and admits it, though not pridefully. The character played by Renee grows throughout the movie into a likable sympathetic woman. I enjoyed this trip across country with the Hamilton family and learning about George's introduction to Hollywood. It is not a laugh a minute comedy but it will make you smile and laugh and challenge you to think. Love the characters and the story line.

reviewText: *** THIS REVIEW IS FOR THE (UK and EUROPE) BLU RAY ISSUE ***In some ways "My One And Only" is a real throwback to old-fashioned filmmaking. It's a story that deliberately takes its own sweet time to unfold - characters make big mistakes, recover begrudgingly, then grow some and move on. It's about a family that's close-knit but also in turmoil - and all of this is set against a backdrop of beautiful Fifties American small town/big city scenery and socially changing times...Renee Zellweger plays Anne Devereaux - a glamorous New York mum who decides to leave her feckless bandleader husband George after she catches him at home with one too many of his on-the-road affairs (a hugely likeable and capable Kevin Bacon). Besides - the royalties to his National hit "My One And Only" have begun to wither - and so with wildly out-of-place optimism - Anne cheerfully bundles her two teenage sons (superb casting of Logan Lerman and Mark Rendall) into her ludicrously flashy Coupe De Ville car (which she's just paid $2,500 for) and hits the road for Pittsburgh - and eventually - the bigger glam of Hollywood. But of course along the way, Anne only manages to flit from one relationship disaster to another - with just her beauty, class and innate belief in herself keeping her head above water and her restless kids out of poverty (and even jail).One of the men she meets and woos is Chris Noth who plays a nice-at-first army-man who is lonely and quickly smitten. But as the relationship unfolds, Harlan increasingly becomes Mister Rules and Regulations - eventually turning into a very nasty piece of work indeed. It's a real departure for Noth from his Mr. Big character in Sex & The City, but man is he good at it (dialogue above).But the film firmly belongs to Zellweger who is absolutely superlative throughout in a way she hasn't been for a long time - ably assisted by a talented supporting cast who are given material that makes everyone shine. Zellweger gives her Anne a beating heart - fun one moment - destroyed the next - digging down deep to find that inner strength to go on. You root for her - bleed for her - and eventually smile at her sheer American tenacity. This movie sees Renee as a great actress rather than just a good one."My One And Only" is a proper journey movie - and because it's steeped in Fifties period architecture and clothing - it looks utterly fantastic on BLU RAY. Scene after scene is filled with that old-world grit, glamour and gorgeous detail. And on it goes to a surprising twist at the end that you genuinely don't see coming. The BLU RAY also features a very informative "Making Of" and staggeringly candid remarks in the "Cast & Crew Interviews" feature (Richard Loncraine the Director and Charlie Peters the Writer) as well as contributions from the army of people who brought the Fifties stuff so evocatively to life.A bit of a 2011 sleeper on the rental and purchase market, I liked "My One And Only" a great deal and bought it to own. I'd say give this little gem a chance - I suspect you'll be more than pleasantly surprised.PS: it's only available on BLU RAY in the 'UK' at present - Stateside is DVD only. Hopefully this situation will change soon...

reviewText: Renee Zellweger shines as Ann, a wife who finds out about her cheating husband and takes her two sons on a road trip in search of new beginning.  The two sons' characters are as smart and deep as well as entertaining and ironic!The family's journey takes us on emotional trips through their souls, dreams and what is really important to them. The story is based on George Hamilton's early life, and the movie surprises you with an amazing cast of great actors.I'm not surprised that these kinds of movies don't make much money; they are just too deep and sensitive to satisfy the seemingly opiate infused minds of average viewers!
summary: to find the one and only meaning of our lives!

reviewText: This movie begins in 1953, the year I was born. I had no expectations when I watched it on TV; I didn't know anything about the movie. I continued to watch because of the cast and the artful, creative opening sequence. I liked that there was no plot, it just kept going on, like real life. The period outfits, cars, sets and hairdos seemed perfect to me. The screenplay never gets boring, it is continually interesting. I recommend this film if you are tired of the same old predictable plots and action sequences.
summary: almost realistic/ no car chases or explosions
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is an interesting film based on the real life experiences growing up by the actor George Hamilton.  His mother Anne is beautiful, classy woman who decides to leave her musician husband when she catches him one too many times in the bed with another woman. It is 1950s, women did not exactly have careers and it was expected of them to stay loyal to their husband if for no other reason than for the reason that they were married to them.  Anne sets on a quest to find herself another husband because after all, she was not really cut out to hold a real job.  She was  a kind of woman who was always taken care of by men.  The fact that she is in her middle age, has two teenage sons from two different men is not stopping her.It is wonderful film (and story) about one woman's endurance and determiantion and the love that binds her with her two sons.  Her constant upbeat attitude is annoying to her sons at times, but they all stick together no matter what.  I never really knew much about George Hamilton, the actor, other than the fact that one point he was engaged to Elizabeth Taylor and they had broken it off on not so friendly terms.  However, this film portrays George as sensitive, cynical and introverted boy determined to seek his own place in his world on his own terms - kind of like what his mother did when she walked out on his father.I truly enjoyed this movie.  Excellent cast of actors!
summary: George Hamilton growing up in unconventional family

reviewText: This movie is so underated.  We went to see it because it was the only adult movie playing last year in September.The movie plays out like movies of the 1940's and 50'... just so entertaining.  It kinda reminds me of Neil Simon plays.Sad that only action flicks and kids animated movies are the movies that we are inundated with today.  I just absolutely loved it !!!  I am watching it the second time and I enjoyed just as much as the first time, maybe more.Just a word of caution, If you are not 60 plus you want understand this movie or probably enjoy it.  It is like movies were when movies were really moviesBack in the 1960's Rene character would have been cast as Vivien Leigh, Jean Simmons, Janet Leigh, and other stars of that era that could have played a lady who life had dealt a blow from which you just don't recover, you just endure.

reviewText: Once again I was ordering this on the premise similar to what you see on the cover: "funny", "cheerful comedy" and the cover showing everyone smiling. There were several lines that were laugh-out-loud funny, but this was more of a drama about an angered wife traveling cross country with her two teen boys to hop from sugar daddy to sugar daddy.The performances were adequate, with even Chris Noth having a brief part as a one of the lunatics she briefly picks to marry. David Koechner plays a great little role as another one of the crazies she tried to marry. Renee plays her role quite well, but it is hard to feel for her as she leap frogs from man to man, uprooting the boys each time as they travel to California from New York. Logan Lerman (who I first remember fromMeet Bill) succinctly plays one of her boys, that if you do not read the art or remember the spoiler ads - gives a nice twist at the end of who he becomes.The picture quality is fine, but it could definitely use a Blu treatment. The sound is 5.1, but the strength of making this 3.5 star film a 5 is the two documentaries. Both last just over 30 minutes each and have a plethora of great material about the making of and creation process. Some of the best moments though are how candid everyone is (especially the writer - Peters) with how broken the Hollywood film making/writing process is. I was laughing harder here than in the film at how sadly honest they were in what it takes to sell a film in Southern California now - worth the watch on their own.Overall, not a solid piece for fans of the supporting cast (Bacon, Noth, Koechner, Stahl) as each only have short appearances. The film hinges on Renee who graces the screen in the way she is known for, and the "twist" of discovering who her kid becomes - but the emotions feel a little shallow. Hope you enjoy.
summary: Would not call this a comedy, but a worthy product overall

reviewerName: The Movie Guy "Movies from A to Z"
reviewText: Kevin Bacon plays Dan Devereaux a NY band leader who has cheated on his wife Anne (Renée Zellweger) one too many times. Dan's claim to fame is that he wrote the hit song, "My One and Only." A song he ironically wrote for Anne.Anne packs up her sons and leaves. Robbie (Mark Rendall) the older son by a different father is stereotypically gay. George (Logan Lerman) is 15 and is mature for his age. He becomes our voice of reason, outsmarting his mom's suitors who are not desirable when she can't see their flaws. Anne is old fashion southern. She is attempting to adapt to the societal changes in post WWII America. Ladies, do not drive. Robbie doesn't have the personality to drive, so unlicensed George is the family chauffeur. Anne instructs her son to look forward and never use the rear view mirror. She is that optimistic. The opening scenes are quick at revealing character.Anne has trouble surviving in the real world, having never lived without being dependent on a man. The film is an enjoyable light comedy and light adventure. For those who like the quirkiness of an indie, and the star acting of a first run feature, this one has it all. Recommended viewing.1 F-bomb, no sex or nudity.
summary: I'M STANDING ON THE EDGE OF SOME CRAZY CLIFF

reviewText: Logan Lerman as the 15 year old George Hamilton, cast alongside the always talented Renée Zellweger as Anne Deveraux and the remarkable Mark Rendall as George's older half-brother, William "Robbie" Potter.Do not miss the most sentimental performance yet from these three briliant stars in the setting of the Old Golden Hollywood Glamour era.
summary: Two Stars for the actor's screen value, Two Stars for the performance
